raw_text:
GM, Ford cut output as sales fall
 
 US car firms General Motors (GM) and Ford have been forced to cut production in the face of falling car sales.
 
 US sales at GM sank 12.7% in February compared to a year ago while Ford sales dropped 3% as foreign rivals took a bigger share of the market. Meanwhile, Asian carmakers fared well - Toyota sales jumped 11% while rival Nissan notched up a 10% increase. Overall. sales across the industry also fell to 1.25 million vehicles from 1.27 million a year earlier.
 
 GM and Ford blamed high fuel prices for low sales of big trucks and gas-guzzling sports utility vehicles (SUVs) - the vehicles that provide the biggest profits.
 
 GM added that US truck sales fell 9% in February while car business tumbled 17%, however it did acknowledge that some new products - such as the Pontiac G6 and Chevrolet Cobalt - had put in solid performances. "The calendar year is starting off slower than expected, both for GM and the industry," said Mark LaNeve, GM's vice president for North American sales, service and marketing. The slump in sales prompted the group to cut production in North America by 3% - it has already reduced output by around 9% in the face of growing stockpiles. Meanwhile, Ford which posted its ninth consecutive drop in monthly US sales, said it was cutting first-quarter North American production by another 10,000 vehicles, or 1.2%. Chrysler, the US unit of Germany's DaimlerChrysler, was the only Detroit based automaker to boast an increase in market share during the month - with sales rising 8%.
 
 But America's loss was its foreign rivals' gain as they continued to nibble away at the US market. While Japan's top car maker Toyota and Nissan saw sales accelerate, even the smaller Suzuki Motor Corp snapped up a more business with sales improving 17.6% on a year ago. In 2003, the firm launched an ambitious plan to triple US sales by 2007 as it seeks to become a bigger player in the Asian assault on the US market. Korea's Hyundai was another big gainer, turning in a 19% surge in February sales. Toyota put its rise in sales down to strong results for its redesigned Avalon sedan and a 120% surge in sales of its gas-electric Prius hybrid mid-size sedan as petrol-price conscious consumers looked to vehicles that were cheaper to run. "As gas prices continue their upward march, fuel efficiency catches the public eye," Jim Press, vice president and chief operating officer of Toyota's US sales arm, said in a statement.
llama3.2:1b:
General Motors (GM) and Ford cut production as car sales fell due to high fuel prices. 

Sales at GM declined by 12.7% in February compared to last year, while Ford saw a drop of 3%. Asian carmakers like Toyota and Nissan had strong performances.

The decline was attributed to the high cost of big trucks and gas-guzzling SUVs. US truck sales fell by 9%, but new products such as the Pontiac G6 and Chevrolet Cobalt performed well.

Ford reduced production in North America by 10,000 vehicles due to falling sales, while GM cut it by 3%. Chrysler's market share increased due to its rise.
llama3.2:3b: US car firms General Motors and Ford cut production due to falling sales, with GM reducing output by 3% and Ford by 1.2%. Sales fell 12.7% at GM and 3% at Ford, while Asian brands like Toyota, Nissan, and Hyundai saw increases.
gemma2:2b:
General Motors and Ford cut production due to falling car sales. Foreign automakers like Toyota and Nissan saw sales increases while US-based companies experienced declines.  High fuel prices are blamed for the decrease in demand for large trucks and SUVs. 
Chrysler saw an increase in market share, although overall US industry sales fell.  
Japanese brands like Suzuki and Korean brands like Hyundai performed well as a result of increased consumer interest in fuel-efficient vehicles.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In the US, car firms General Motors (GM) and Ford cut production amid falling car sales, with GM blaming high fuel prices for low sales of big trucks and SUVs, while Ford posted an 8% increase in monthly North American production after cutting first-quarter output by another 10,000 vehicles. However, Toyota's sales were growing stronger as its redesigned Avalon sedan showed strong results, Hyundai's sales rose 19%, and Nissan's mid-size sedan sales improved 120%.
qwen2.5:1.5b: US car firms General Motors (GM) and Ford have cut production due to falling sales, while Asian rivals, especially Toyota, saw increased market share. Toyota reported 11% growth in February sales.
qwen2.5:3b: US car firms General Motors (GM) and Ford have cut production due to falling car sales. GM saw a 12.7% drop in February compared to a year ago with Ford sales dropping 3%. Sales across the industry fell from 1.27 million to 1.25 million vehicles. High fuel prices led to reduced sales of big trucks and SUVs, which provide high profits for manufacturers. GM and Ford both blamed this on higher fuel costs, though GM acknowledged that some new products performed well. The overall trend showed a decline in the US market with only Chrysler seeing an increase in its share. Foreign competitors like Toyota and Nissan gained ground at the expense of domestic brands, with Japan's Suzuki increasing sales 17.6% from a year earlier and Hyundai experiencing a 19% rise. Toyota attributes its sales growth to new model introductions and improved fuel-efficient hybrid vehicles.
opencoder:1.5b:
GM and Ford have been forced to cut production due to the fall in sales compared to the previous year as foreign rivals took over the market.

The rise in sales from Japan and Korea are major successes for GM and Ford as they continue to grow their business. Toyota's Avalon sedan and a gas-electric Prius hybrid mid-size sedan provide strong results for fuel efficiency as consumers look to vehicles that are cheaper to run on a per-gallon basis. The increase in sales is due to continued growth of the company's business.

The rise in Japanese top car makers like Toyota, Nissan, and Suzuki Motor Corp has contributed positively to the overall sales fall. In addition, America's loss was driven by the foreign rivals' gain as they continued to cut back at the US market.

Despite Japan's strong sales, Korea's Hyundai has consistently shown strong growth due to increased demand for electric cars and improved fuel efficiency. The rise in Japanese top car makers like Toyota and Nissan is offset by the potential profit margins from electric vehicles that are cheaper to run on a per-gallon basis.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and conveys the main ideas:

1. GM and Ford cut output as sales fall due to falling car sales.
2. US sales at GM sank 12.7% in February compared to a year ago while Ford sales dropped 3% as foreign rivals take a bigger share of the market.
3. US sales across the industry also fell to 1.25 million vehicles from 1.27 million a year earlier.
4. GM and Ford blamed high fuel prices for low sales of big trucks and SUVs - the vehicles that provide the biggest profits.
5. GM added that US truck sales fell 9% in February while car business tumbled 17%, however it did acknowledge that some new products, such as the Pontiac G6 and Chevrolet Cobalt, had put in solid performances. "The calendar year is starting off slower than expected, both for GM and the industry," said Mark LaNeve, GM's vice president for North American sales, service and marketing.
6. Meanwhile, Ford which posted its ninth consecutive drop in monthly US sales, said it was cutting first-quarter North American production by another 10,000 vehicles, or 1.2%. Chrysler, the US unit of Germany's DaimlerChrysler, was the only Detroit based automaker to boast an increase in market share during the month - with sales rising 8%.
7. But America's loss was its foreign rivals' gain as they continued to nibble away at the US market. While Japan's top car maker Toyota and Nissan saw sales accelerate, even the smaller Suzuki Motor Corp snapped up a more business with sales improving 17.6% on a year ago. In 2003, the firm launched an ambitious plan to triple US sales by 2007 as it seeks to become a bigger player in the Asian assault on the US market.
8. Korea's Hyundai was another big gainer, turning in a 19% surge in February sales. Toyota put its rise in sales down to strong results for its redesigned Avalon sedan and a 120% surge in sales of its gas-electric Prius hybrid mid-size sedan as petrol-price conscious consumers looked to vehicles that were cheaper to run. "As fuel prices continue their upward march, fuel efficiency catches the public eye," Jim Press, vice president and chief operating officer of Toyota's US sales arm, said in a statement.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about GM and Ford's car sales trends in February 2003. Let me read through it carefully.

The first paragraph mentions that GM and Ford were forced to cut output when sales dropped because fuel prices were high for big trucks and SUVs. They blamed fuel prices on low sales of those vehicles, which made them lose profits. Then, GM says their truck sales fell 9% and car business tumbled 17%. Some new products like the G6 and Cobalt did well.

Ford's part is also about sales dropping by 3%, but they're cutting production in North America even though sales are down. They cut first-quarter production by another 10,000 or about 1.2%. Chrysler is up in market share from last year.

The user said the focus is on key ideas and details, so I need to capture the main points without getting too detailed. GM had a mixed outlook: sales fell for big SUVs but improved with new products, leading them to cut production. Ford was losing in car business but gained in trucks or SUVs. The industry as a whole also lost.

I should keep it concise, just the summary. No explanations needed. So I'll mention that both companies were affected by fuel prices and sales trends, their cuts, and overall industry performance.
</think>

GM and Ford had to cut production due to falling sales caused by high fuel prices affecting big SUVs and gas-guzzling vehicles. GM's trucks and SUVs sales fell 9%, while car business dropped 17%. New products like the G6 and Cobalt performed well, boosting GM's profits. Ford faced a 3% drop in US car sales but reduced North American production by another 10,000 or about 1.2%. Chrysler saw an 8% rise in sales. The industry overall lost 1.25 million vehicles, with GM and Ford cutting in February.
tinyllama:1.1b: In response to the declining car sales in the United States, both General Motors (GM) and Ford have reportedly cut production and slashed sales in North America by 3% and 10,000 vehicles respectively for the month of February. In contrast, Asian automakers, including Toyota and Suzuki Motor Corp., saw gains despite the negative impact of high fuel prices. Despite this decline in car sales, Ford also reportedly slashed first-quarter North American production by another 10,000 vehicles, or 1.2%, to ensure enough stocks for demand. This comes amidst growing stockpiles due to increasing stockpiles of inventory across the industry. Toyota's market share in the United States was boosted by its expansion plans into North America, which includes launching a new product lineup for 2003. Meanwhile, Suzuki Motor Corp. Surged 17.6% despite launching an aggressive plan to triple US sales by 2007 as part of its strategy to become a bigger player in the Asian assault on the US market.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Ford slashed production in North America by approximately 3% as it tried to curb its market share losses and cope with lower sales due to rising fuel prices. GM, the second-largest automaker globally, also had to make significant cuts to try and maintain a competitive edge in an increasingly tough market. Despite the negative impact of higher fuel costs on their operations, the US car manufacturers managed to boost production at some plants by around 10,000 units. Chrysler, another Detroit-based automaker, was able to increase its market share during the month due to strong sales of its vehicles in Europe. However, this success wasn't enough to offset the overall slump in car sales across the US, which dropped by approximately 17% in February from a year ago.
phi:2.7b: GM and Ford cut production due to falling car sales caused by high fuel prices. Other foreign carmakers such as Toyota, Nissan, and Volkswagen saw an increase in sales during the same time period. The slump has prompted the two companies to reduce North American production while Japan's top carmaker, Toyota, is expected to triple US sales by 2007.
orca-mini:3b: US car firms General Motors (GM) and Ford have been forced to cut production due to falling sales, blaming high fuel prices for low truck and SUV sales. The group has reduced output by around 9% and announced further cuts of 1.2% for the first quarter, with the loss of 3%. GM and Ford acknowledged that some new products, such as the Pontiac G6 and Chevrolet Cobalt, had performed well in the face of weaker demand overall. However, Chrysler, which is part of DaimlerChrysler, was the only Detroit-based automaker to see an increase in market share during the month.
hermes3:3b: GM and Ford cut production due to 12.7% drop in GM US sales and 3% drop in Ford sales. High fuel prices blamed for decrease in truck & gas-guzzling SUVs. Production reduced by 3% for GM, 10,000 vehicles for Ford. Foreign rivals like Toyota & Nissan gain market share.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: US car manufacturers General Motors (GM) and Ford have reduced production due to falling car sales. GM's sales fell 12.7% in February, with Ford experiencing a 3% drop, as foreign rivals took a larger share of the market. Asian carmakers performed well with Toyota seeing an 11% increase in sales and Nissan notching up a 10% rise. Sales across the industry declined from 1.27 million to 1.25 million vehicles. GM and Ford blamed high fuel prices for low sales of large trucks and gas-guzzling SUVs, which provide the biggest profits. The slump in sales prompted GM to cut production by 3%, while Ford reduced output by 10,000 vehicles in Q1. Foreign rivals continued to gain market share, with Toyota, Nissan, Suzuki, Hyundai, and even Chrysler experiencing growth in sales.
chatgpt-4o-latest: GM and Ford are cutting production due to declining US car sales, with GM sales dropping 12.7% and Ford 3% in February. High fuel prices have hurt demand for large trucks and SUVs, their most profitable vehicles. GM's truck sales fell 9% and car sales 17%, leading to a 3% production cut, following a previous 9% reduction. Ford, facing its ninth consecutive monthly sales decline, is reducing first-quarter production by 1.2%. Meanwhile, Chrysler saw an 8% sales increase. Foreign automakers gained market share, with Toyota and Nissan sales rising 11% and 10%, respectively, and Hyundai surging 19%. Toyota attributed its growth to strong sales of the redesigned Avalon and a 120% increase in Prius hybrid sales, driven by rising fuel prices.
stablelm2:1.6b: US car firms General Motors (GM) and Ford have cut production due to falling car sales, with GM sinking 7% in February compared to a year ago and Ford dropping 3%. The blame is on big trucks and gas-guzzling sports utility vehicles (SUVs), which provide the biggest profits. Both companies have reduced output by around 9% and another 12% for Ford. In contrast, Asian carmakers like Toyota and Nissan have seen sales accelerate, with Suzuki's sales also improving 6%. Ford aims to triple US sales in three years as it seeks to become a bigger player in the Asian assault on the US market.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
US car manufacturers General Motors (GM) and Ford have reduced production due to plummeting car sales. In February, GM experienced a 12.7% drop in sales, while Ford saw an 8% decline. High fuel prices contributed to the decrease in demand for large trucks and gas-guzzling SUVs, profitable segments for these companies.

Asian carmakers, notably Toyota (up 11%) and Nissan (up 10%), capitalized on this market shift. Toyota attributed its growth to strong sales of the redesigned Avalon sedan and the popular Prius hybrid vehicle, emphasizing that fuel efficiency was a significant factor in consumer purchases amidst rising gas prices.

Meanwhile, Chrysler, the US unit of German automaker DaimlerChrysler, was the only Detroit-based company to show an increase in market share (8%). The overall industry sales dropped to 1.25 million vehicles from 1.27 million in the previous year.

In response to the slowing demand, GM cut first-quarter North American production by 3%, and Ford reduced output by 10,000 vehicles or 1.2%. This production adjustment comes after both companies had previously reduced output by around 9% due to growing inventory levels.
reference: US sales at GM sank 12.7% in February compared to a year ago while Ford sales dropped 3% as foreign rivals took a bigger share of the market.In 2003, the firm launched an ambitious plan to triple US sales by 2007 as it seeks to become a bigger player in the Asian assault on the US market.Chrysler, the US unit of Germany's DaimlerChrysler, was the only Detroit based automaker to boast an increase in market share during the month - with sales rising 8%.GM added that US truck sales fell 9% in February while car business tumbled 17%, however it did acknowledge that some new products - such as the Pontiac G6 and Chevrolet Cobalt - had put in solid performances.While Japan's top car maker Toyota and Nissan saw sales accelerate, even the smaller Suzuki Motor Corp snapped up a more business with sales improving 17.6% on a year ago.US car firms General Motors (GM) and Ford have been forced to cut production in the face of falling car sales.Meanwhile, Ford which posted its ninth consecutive drop in monthly US sales, said it was cutting first-quarter North American production by another 10,000 vehicles, or 1.2%.
